bioghist.p: The Friends Neighborhood Guild is a settlement house serving the Poplar section of North Philadelphia. The organization was founded in 1879 and was originally called the Friends Beach Street Mission. In 1899, the organization was renamed the Friends Neighborhood Guild. The Guild was involved in the redevelopment of East Poplar. In 1950, the Guild started the Friends Self Help Cooperative, one of the most successful housing cooperatives in Philadelphia. The cooperative subsequently purchased Penn Towne, a Redevelopment Authority housing project at Seventh and Fairmount Streets. The Guild also established Operation Poplar, an extensive outreach program that involved the Guild in housing, community organizing, juvenile counseling, urban renewal, small businesses, and other facets of neighborhood life.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains administrative records, scrapbooks, photographs, slides, and audiovisual materials of the Friends Neighborhood Guild. Materials include: board minutes, agendas, and reports; annual reports, 1984-1990; correspondence, including appeals, thank you letters, and correspondence with staff of community organizations and city agencies; agreements with agencies and organizations such as the Energy Coordinating Agency; grant proposals and grant reports; files on aid recipients; minutes, memoranda, financial information, and correspondence related to the Friends Rehabilitation Program (2001-2004), the Greater Philadelphia Federation of Settlements, and the Philadelphia Housing Authority; and some routine office forms and files. These records include the files of two executive directors, Phillip G. Fazah and Francis Bosworth. There is a good deal of information about the organization's finances, including: budgets and monthly reports 1933-1956; pension plan and payroll files; personnel retirement records; general ledger and journal, 1984-1986; audits, 1990s; and copies of invoices, receipts, and checks, 1980s-1990s. Scrapbooks, 1954-55 and 1960-61, contains clippings, programs, flyers, and photographs. There are also photographs and slides of Friends Neighborhood Guild events and activities (ranging in date from the early 20th century to the 1990s), as well as videos and audiocassettes from various social welfare organizations and programs, including the United Way and the Children's Defense Fund.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
